perturbation.original_text: 1.1 Confidential Information shall mean all non-public information of a Party, which is disclosed to the other Party hereunder, including,  without limitation, trade secrets, technical information, business information, sales information, marketing information, customer-buying patterns,  algorithms, customer and potential customer lists and identities, product sales plans, sublicense agreements, inventions, developments,  discoveries, software, know-how, methods, techniques, formulae, data, processes and other trade secrets and proprietary ideas, whether or not protectable under patent, trademark, copyright or other areas of law, and any other information marked as "proprietary"  or "confidential" at the  time of disclosure. Notwithstanding the foregoing, "Confidential Information" shall not include any information that (a) was or has become  publicly available without restriction through no fault of the receiving Party or its employees or agents; (b) is received without restriction from a  third party that, to the best knowledge of the receiving Party, did not have an obligation of confidentiality to the disclosing Party; (c) was  rightfully in possession of the receiving Party without restriction prior to its disclosure by the other Party; or (d) was independently developed by  employees of the receiving Party that had no knowledge of or access to such information, as evidenced by written records of the receiving Party.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.1 Confidential Information shall mean all non-public information of a Party, which is disclosed to the other Party hereunder, including,  without limitation, trade secrets, technical information, business information, sales information, marketing information, customer-buying patterns,  algorithms, customer and potential customer lists and identities, product sales plans, sublicense agreements, inventions, developments,  discoveries, software, know-how, methods, techniques, formulae, data, processes and other trade secrets and proprietary ideas, whether or not protectable under patent, trademark, copyright or other areas of law, and any other information marked as "proprietary"  or "confidential" at the  time of disclosure. Notwithstanding the foregoing, "Confidential Information" shall not include any information that (a) was or has become  publicly available without restriction; (b) is received from a  third party; (c) was  in possession of the receiving Party prior to its disclosure by the other Party; or (d) was developed by  employees of the receiving Party.
perturbation.explanation: This modification removes the key qualifiers regarding the exceptions to Confidential Information. Removing "through no fault of the receiving Party or its employees or agents" from (a), "without restriction from a third party that, to the best knowledge of the receiving Party, did not have an obligation of confidentiality to the disclosing Party" from (b), "rightfully in possession of the receiving Party without restriction" from (c), and "independently developed by employees of the receiving Party that had no knowledge of or access to such information, as evidenced by written records of the receiving Party." from (d) broadens the exceptions, making the definition of Confidential Information so vague as to be practically unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Varies by jurisdiction, but general contract law requires clear and unambiguous definitions, especially for key terms like "Confidential Information."

perturbation.original_text: 1.3 Day Rate shall mean the daily rate at which Rubicon will provide services to ISA or ISA Clients. The Day Rate for each type of service  provided will be as per the rate card set out in Exhibit C, such rates to be subject to annual review by the Parties on the anniversary of this  Agreement provided that such rates may be reviewed on an ad hoc basis at any time should the Parties become aware of specific information  which impacts on the validity or feasibility of the Day Rate.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.3 Day Rate shall mean the suggested rate at which Rubicon will provide services to ISA or ISA Clients. The Day Rate for each type of service  provided will be generally similar to the rate card set out in Exhibit C, such rates being subject to review by Rubicon at any time based on market conditions.
perturbation.explanation: The term "Day Rate" is made ambiguous by changing "daily rate" to "suggested rate", removing the commitment to Exhibit C, and giving Rubicon unilateral power to adjust rates based on undefined "market conditions". This contradicts the original intent of a fixed day rate, creating uncertainty in payment obligations and disputes over pricing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law requires clear pricing terms; this modification makes the pricing term vague and unilaterally adjustable, potentially unenforceable.

perturbation.original_text: 5.2.1 As regards Intellectual Property created by Rubicon, Rubicon acknowledges and agrees that those Works, as defined below,  shall belong exclusively to ISA subject to payment in accordance with clause 4.2. Works means, collectively, any work product (of any type),  software, developments, processes, improvements, and all works of authorship, in whole or in part, whether patentable or not and whether  copyrightable or not created as services provided directly to ISA or on behalf of ISA by Rubicon, which (i) are conceived or made by Rubicon, its  employees, contractors, consultants or agents during the Term and relate directly to the business in which ISA and Rubicon(during the Term by ISA) are, had been or were proposing to be engaged in; or (ii) are conceived or made by Rubicon, its employees, contractors, consultants or  agents during or after the Term and are made through the use of any ISA Confidential Information, or which result from any work performed by  Rubicon, its employees, contractors, consultants or agents for ISA. It is agreed that the terms under which Rubicon agrees to work with ISA,  including the Day Rate, reflect and will reflect any value or potential value of Intellectual Property created by Rubicon on behalf of ISA.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.2.1 As regards Intellectual Property created by Rubicon, Rubicon acknowledges and agrees that those Works, as defined below,  may belong to ISA subject to discretionary payment. Works means, collectively, any work product (of any type),  software, developments, processes, improvements, and all works of authorship, in whole or in part, created as services provided directly to ISA or on behalf of ISA by Rubicon, which (i) relate generally to the projects ISA and Rubicon may consider; or (ii) are made by Rubicon and may relate to information shared between parties. It is agreed that the terms under which Rubicon agrees to work with ISA,  including the Day Rate, may not reflect any value of Intellectual Property created by Rubicon on behalf of ISA.
perturbation.explanation: Modifying "shall belong exclusively" to "may belong", "subject to payment in accordance with clause 4.2" to "subject to discretionary payment", removing "whether patentable or not and whether copyrightable or not", changing "relate directly to the business in which ISA and Rubicon are, had been or were proposing to be engaged in; or (ii) are conceived or made by Rubicon, its employees, contractors, consultants or agents during or after the Term and are made through the use of any ISA Confidential Information, or which result from any work performed by  Rubicon, its employees, contractors, consultants or agents for ISA" to "relate generally to the projects ISA and Rubicon may consider; or (ii) are made by Rubicon and may relate to information shared between parties", and modifying "reflect and will reflect any value or potential value of Intellectual Property created by Rubicon on behalf of ISA" to "may not reflect any value of Intellectual Property created by Rubicon on behalf of ISA" makes ownership of works unclear, weakens ISA's claim and creates ambiguity regarding consideration for IP.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Intellectual property law requires clear assignment of rights; this modification creates ambiguity that would make enforcing IP rights difficult.
